 For instance: Can you name anyone who is against reducing crime? Have you ever run across anyone, liberal or conservative, who has said anything like, "I sure wish violent crime would go up."
 
 No. Yet, I personally believe using an inanimate object (a tool) such as a gun, to protect myself will reduce crime. If everyone carried one, who would you choose to rob/rape/assault? Why do the police carry them? Protection? Why is a gun good for their protection, yet bad for mine?

We have to figure out a way to vote for a third alternative, or else we'll find that the two party groove we've been riding in is too hard to get out of.  I think what the US needs is what the UK needs - at a minimum an Alternative Vote electoral system and ideally a mixed PR and AV system. Well, over here the police don't carry guns, because they're not likely to face people with guns.

 
 So, nobody owns fire extinguishers? They're not likely to have a house fire.
 
 I'm guessing life jackets for boaters are also scorned over there. After all, drownings are very infrequent.
 
 Why wear seat belts? Few people are "likely" to get into an auto accident.

So, nobody owns fire extinguishers? They're not likely to have a house fire.

 
 In private homes? No. Smoke detector and a fire blanket are fairly common. Standard practice in a fire in a private home is get everyone out, closing doors behind you and let the fire brigade deal with it. We pay part of our council tax to train professionals, it's safer all round if they're allowed to get on with their job. Plus almost all our housing is brick or stonework, so holds up longer in a fire and can be repaired more easily.
 
 The police don't carry guns because they don't need them, and the consequences of accidents and screw-ups are much greater when you've shot someone in the chest as opposed to hitting them with a baton or CS spray. There is a big difference between a life jacket or seatbelt where the only function is lifesaving, and a gun which is intended to kill.

 Psychologists & others have studied (& are still studying) political ideology & orientation & quite often the data seems to point toward 2 broad but distinct political phenotypes. The jury is still out on much of the findings, still under peer review, seeking replication, even twin studies, etc. Rather than describing views as conservative or liberal, they seem to be concentrating on the underlying, often seemingly innate differences in beliefs among the 2 broad groups. Fr'instance - 
 
 
Alford et al. argue that "genes influence people's outlooks and personalities, and it is these broad features that then predispose individuals toward suites of specific attitudes" (164). The authors theorize that two "political phenotypes" (or personality types) underlie conservatism and liberalism: absolutist and contextualist (164-165). The "absolutist" type is characterized by a suspicion of out-groups, a yearning for in-group unity and strong leadership, a desire for clear and unbending rules, and a fondness for retribution; the "contextualist" is characterized by tolerance toward out-groups, a context-dependent (as opposed to rule-based) approach to proper behavior, support for equality, and greater empathy. 2
 
 2 The authors do not mention that the absolutist type is nearly identical to the "authoritarian personality" (see, e.g. Adorno et al. 1950; Altemeyer 1996; Feldman 2003; Stenner 2005).
 http://sitemaker.umich.edu/suhay/files/critique_of_twin_studies_--_suhay__kalmoe__mcdermott_101007.pdf

Right-wing authoritarianism (RWA) is a personality and ideological variable studied in political, social, and personality psychology. It is defined by three attitudinal and behavioral clusters which correlate together:[1][2]
 
 1.Authoritarian submission - a high degree of submissiveness to the authorities who are perceived to be established and legitimate in the society in which one lives.
 2.Authoritarian aggression - a general aggressiveness directed against deviants, outgroups, and other people that are perceived to be targets according to established authorities.
 3.Conventionalism - a high degree of adherence to the traditions and social norms that are perceived to be endorsed by society and its established authorities, and a belief that others in one's society should also be required to adhere to these norms[3].
